/wiki/Aberdare_(UK_Parliament_constituen: Aberdare was a constituency in the Parliament of the United Kingdom. It was created for the 1918 general election and returned one Member of Parliament (MP) by the first past the post system until it was abolished for the 1983 general election. The Labour Party captured the seat in 1922 and held it comfortably until its abolition
/wiki/Thomas_Evan_Nicholas_(Niclas_y_Gla: Thomas Evan Nicholas (6 October 1879 – 19 April 1971), who used the bardic name "Niclas y Glais" (English: '"Nicholas of Glais"'), was a Welsh language poet, preacher, radical, and champion of the disadvantaged of society.
/wiki/Accrington_(UK_Parliament_constitu: Accrington was a parliamentary constituency of the House of Commons of the Parliament of the United Kingdom from 1885 to 1983. It elected one Member of Parliament (MP) by the first-past-the-post system of election.
/wiki/Charles_Roden_Buxton: Charles Roden Buxton (27 November 1875 – 16 December 1942) was an English philanthropist and radical British Liberal Party politician who later joined the Labour Party. He survived an assassination attempt during a mission to the Balkans in 1914.
/wiki/Ayr_Burghs_(UK_Parliament_constitu: Ayr Burghs was a district of burghs constituency of the House of Commons of the Parliament of Great Britain from 1708 to 1800 and of the House of Commons of the Parliament of the United Kingdom from 1801 to 1950. It elected one Member of Parliament (MP), using the first-past-the-post voting system.
/wiki/Campbell_Stephen: Reverend Campbell Stephen (1884 – 25 October 1947) was a Scottish socialist politician.
/wiki/Bermondsey_West_(UK_Parliament_con: Bermondsey West was a parliamentary constituency centred on the Bermondsey district of South London.  It returned one Member of Parliament to the House of Commons of the Parliament of the United Kingdom.
/wiki/Alfred_Salter: Alfred Salter (16 June 1873 – 24 August 1945) was a British medical practitioner and Labour Party politician.
/wiki/Birmingham_Ladywood_(UK_Parliament: Birmingham, Ladywood is a constituency[n 1] of part of the city of Birmingham, represented in the House of Commons.[n 2]
/wiki/John_Kneeshaw: John William Kneeshaw (25 August 1878 – 25 October 1960) was a British political activist.
/wiki/Blackburn_(UK_Parliament_constitue: Blackburn is a constituency[n 1] represented in the House of Commons of the UK Parliament.[n 2]
/wiki/Philip_Snowden: Philip Snowden, 1st Viscount Snowden, PC (/ˈsnoʊdən/; 18 July 1864 – 15 May 1937) was a British politician. A strong speaker, he became popular in trade union circles for his denunciation of capitalism as unethical and his promise of a socialist utopia.  He was the first Labour Chancellor of the Exchequer, a position he held in 1924 and again between 1929 and 1931. He broke with Labour policy in 1931, and was expelled from the party and excoriated as a turncoat, as the Party was overwhelmingly crushed that year by the National Government coalition that Snowden supported. He was succeeded as Chancellor by Neville Chamberlain.
/wiki/Bosworth_(UK_Parliament_constituen: Bosworth /bɒzwərθ/ is a constituency[n 1] represented since 2019 by Luke Evans, a Conservative.[n 2]
/wiki/Thomas_Richardson_(Labour_Party_MP: Thomas Richardson (6 June 1868 – 22 October 1928) was a Labour Party politician in the United Kingdom who served as Member of Parliament (MP) for Whitehaven, in Cumberland, from 1910 to 1918.
/wiki/Bradford_Central_(UK_Parliament_co: Bradford Central was a parliamentary constituency in the city of Bradford, West Yorkshire, which returned one Member of Parliament (MP) to the House of Commons of the Parliament of the United Kingdom. Elections were held under the first-past-the-post voting system.
/wiki/William_Leach_(Labour_politician): William Leach (1870 – 21 November 1949) was a British Labour Party politician.
/wiki/Bradford_East_(UK_Parliament_const: Bradford East is a constituency[n 1] represented in the House of Commons of the UK Parliament. [n 2]
/wiki/Frederick_William_Jowett: Frederick William Jowett (31 January 1864 – 1 February 1944) was a British Labour politician.
/wiki/Brigg_(UK_Parliament_constituency): Brigg was a county constituency centred on the town of Brigg in North Lincolnshire.  It returned one Member of Parliament (MP) to the House of Commons of the Parliament of the United Kingdom, elected by the first-past-the-post voting system.
/wiki/David_Quibell,_1st_Baron_Quibell: David John Kinsley Quibell, 1st Baron Quibell (21 December 1879 – 16 April 1962) was a British builder, contractor and Labour Party politician.
/wiki/Bristol_East_(UK_Parliament_consti: Bristol East is a constituency[n 1] recreated in 1983 covering the eastern part of the City of Bristol. [n 2] An earlier guise of the seat existed between 1885 and 1950.
/wiki/Luke_Bateman_(trade_unionist): Luke Henry Bateman (born 1873) was a British trade unionist and politician.  He repeatedly narrowly missed out on election to Parliament.
/wiki/Camberwell_North_(UK_Parliament_co:
Camberwell North was a borough constituency located in the Metropolitan Borough of Camberwell, in South London.  It returned one Member of Parliament (MP) to the House of Commons of the Parliament of the United Kingdom.
The constituency was created for the 1885 general election, and abolished for the 1950 general election.
/wiki/Charles_Ammon,_1st_Baron_Ammon: Charles George Ammon, 1st Baron Ammon, PC, DL, JP (22 April 1873 – 2 April 1960) was a British Labour Party politician.
/wiki/Cardiff_Central_(UK_Parliament_con: Cardiff Central (Welsh: Canol Caerdydd) is a borough constituency in the city of Cardiff. It returns one Member of Parliament (MP) to the House of Commons of the Parliament of the United Kingdom, elected by the first past the post system.
/wiki/James_Ewart_Edmunds: James Ewart Edmunds (5 May 1882 – 1962) was a Welsh trade unionist and politician.
/wiki/Chorley_(UK_Parliament_constituenc: Chorley is a constituency[n 1][n 2] in Lancashire represented in the House of Commons of the UK Parliament since 1997 by Lindsay Hoyle. Hoyle was originally elected for the Labour Party, but in 2019 became the Speaker, making him unaffiliated.
/wiki/Elijah_Sandham:
Elijah Sandham (1875 – 7 May 1944)
was an English Independent Labour Party (ILP) politician from Lancashire. He sat in the House of Commons from 1929 to 1931 as the Member of Parliament (MP) for Kirkdale division of Liverpool, and in 1934 he led the breakaway Independent Socialist Party.
/wiki/Colne_Valley_(UK_Parliament_consti: Colne Valley is a constituency[n 1] represented in the House of Commons of the UK Parliament since 2019 by Jason McCartney of the Conservative Party.[n 2]  The seat has been won by three different parties' candidates by a marginal majority since the 1992 general election, the last occasion when the winning majority exceeded 10% of the votes cast.
/wiki/Wilfrid_Whiteley: Wilfrid Whiteley (3 February 1882 – 4 April 1970) was a British Labour Party politician.
/wiki/Coventry_(UK_Parliament_constituen: Coventry was a borough constituency  which was represented in the House of Commons of England and its successors, the House of Commons of Great Britain and the House of Commons of the United Kingdom.
/wiki/Richard_Collingham_Wallhead: Richard Collingham Wallhead (28 December 1869 – 27 April 1934), known as R. C. Wallhead, was a British Member of Parliament.
/wiki/Dewsbury_(UK_Parliament_constituen: Dewsbury is a constituency[n 1] created in 1868. This seat is represented in the House of Commons of the United Kingdom Parliament since 2019 by Mark Eastwood of the Conservative Party.[n 2]
/wiki/Benjamin_Riley: Benjamin Riley (1866 – 6 January 1946) was a British Labour Party politician.
/wiki/Dunbartonshire_(UK_Parliament_cons: Dunbartonshire was a county constituency of the House of Commons of Great Britain (at Westminster) from 1708 to 1801 and of the House of Commons of the Parliament of the United Kingdom (also Westminster) from 1801 to 1950.
/wiki/William_Henry_Porteous_Martin: William Henry Porteous Martin (15 June 1886 – 9 January 1939) was a Scottish Labour Party politician. He was Member of Parliament (MP) for Dunbartonshire from 1923 to 1924.
/wiki/Edinburgh_Central_(UK_Parliament_c: Edinburgh Central was a burgh constituency of the House of Commons of the Parliament of the United Kingdom (at Westminster) from 1885 to 2005. It elected one Member of Parliament (MP) by the first past the post system of election.
/wiki/William_Graham_(Edinburgh_MP): William Graham PC (29 July 1887 – 8 January 1932) was a Scottish Labour politician.
/wiki/Glasgow_Bridgeton_(UK_Parliament_c: Glasgow Bridgeton was a parliamentary constituency in the city of Glasgow.  From 1885 to 1974, it returned one Member of Parliament (MP) to the House of Commons of the Parliament of the United Kingdom, elected by the first-past-the-post voting system.
/wiki/James_Maxton: James Maxton (22 June 1885 – 23 July 1946) was a British left-wing politician, and leader of the far-left faction of the Independent Labour Party. He was a pacifist who opposed both world wars. A prominent proponent of Home Rule for Scotland, he is remembered as one of the leading figures of the Red Clydeside era. He broke with Ramsay MacDonald and the second minority Labour government, and became one of its most bitter critics. As the leader of the Independent Labour Party (ILP), he disaffiliated the ILP from the mainstream party in 1932. After that he was a marginal independent figure on the far left-wing.
